reviewText: This review might help some other potential viewers who feel the same way about Adam Sandler as I do. For the record, I CAN'T STAND him at all. I do NOT think he is funny at all. I watched many of his SNL skits over the years. He should have been fired he was SO unfunny. His sense of humor flat out sucked.So why would I bother then if I can't stand him? I read DOZENS of reviews about The Wedding Singer. I knew he was in it. It really sounded STUPID, and the fact that Adam Sandler was in it was the reason I wouldn't watch it. As I have said, I don't find him funny at all. He SNL humor just sucks.The ONLY reason I watched The Wedding Singer is because of the 80's theme. I am a HUGE 80's fan, and I wanted to see how they revived the decade. I finally watched it a few days ago and it was actually VERY funny. I don't like romantic comedies at all (romantic comedy is like Microsoft and stable, they should never be in the same sentence). After I finished The Wedding Singer and saw that he actually CAN be funny outside of SNL, I decided to give Happy Gilmore a shot.The first thing that comes to mind is this movie seems to be a take off on Caddyshack. While they might not have tried to rip it off, they seemed to. Some of the scenes are so funny that I had to pause it I was laughing so hard. One of the earliest scenes that I found hilarious is when he was playing golf during a live broadcast. He couldn't hit the ball right and started beating it with his club, then every other word was swearing. The scene cut to the executives office with the TV in the background and all you heard was <bleep> word <bleep> word <bleep bleep> word <bleep> you son of <bleep> you mother <bleep> <bleep>. After that scene was over I was still laughing for a good 2 minutes. He does that a lot in the movie.The plot outline is that he grew up wanting to be a hockey player, but was always rejected. He visits his grandmother (I think thats who she was), and finds out her house is getting reposessed because she hasn't paid her taxes in over 10 years. Somehow he winds up on the golf course and finds out that he can hit the ball HUNDREDS of yards. After talks with a coach and several failed attempts, he reluctantly joins a golf tournament in an effort to win enough money to buy her house back. He meets up with a legendary golfer who he is trying to beat in the tournament for the money and a trophy.There is more to it than that, but this should give you an overview of what the movie is about.Essentially, I'm writing this because I do know of some others who can't stand Adam Sandler either. He was in my top 5 of most hated comedians. I have seen his acting on SNL, some of his stand up comedy, and it just was NOT funny.Well so far I have seen The Wedding Singer, Happy Gilmore, and Little Nicky. All were pretty funny. Not the funniest I have ever seen, but for someone who can't stand him as much as me, I was pretty surprised that I liked them.His attitude during the movie is great. He loses his cool, wants to physically beat people and objects, curses CONSTANTLY, and some of his one liners are admittedly VERY funny. If you remember the bar scene with the one liners that rhymed, then you know what I mean. I won't spoil it by telling.Even if you can't stand and completely despise Adam Sandler (like me), give his movies a shot. His acting and comedy outside SNL is better in my opinion. I will never watch his SNL performances again.Happy Gilmore is basically Caddyshack with fighting, cursing, and funny one liners.

reviewText: What I loved about this movie was the ACTING. It works because Adam Sandler is brllliantly "real" at all times, even though he plays a silly character in silly situations. His commitment to the role is  breathtaking. Somehow you really believe this character would punch out his  caddy, go beserk on national television, have a heated argument with a  golfball, and threaten a plastic clown face with death! Yet at the same  time, the character has an innocence and guilelessness that allows us to  forgive him his excentricities. He's just an Everyman who is out of his  element, trying to find his way. If he causes tumult and chaos in the area  around him, it is forgivable because he is only doing what he has been  trained to do, for all of his previous life. "Happy" remains a  likeable character even while he is punching out Bob Barker! That is the  genius of this movie.People might tell you the plot of this movie, and  all the funny skits that are in this movie, but you still might not get it.  I don't think I would have "gotten it" just by hearing a  recounting of the plot. The script is funny, and it's a good vehicle, but  the reason I have watched this movie over and over again is because Adam  Sandler is SUCH a good actor. He makes you BELIEVE. Comedians never get  enough credit for this, but in a movie like this one, which is really a  pretty bizarre situation, it is his ability to take us into a mode of  suspended reality that makes the movie work: he makes the incredible  plausible. Bravo!

reviewText: It's an idea crazy enough to work.  Take Adam Sandler and put him on the PGA tour, then sit back and wait for the hilarity to ensue.  Happy Gilmore is one of the funniest films of the 1990s, and it is actually pretty uplifting to all of us who love to cheer for the underdog.  There's nothing really intellectual about this film, and that's perfectly OK.  We have our underdog, Happy Gilmore; his only dream in life is to be a professional hockey player, but the only thing he brings to the ice is a quick temper.  Then we have the lovable grandmother put in a precarious situation-her house, which her own late husband built, has been seized by the government as a result of her not paying taxes for ten years.  Happy accidentally discovers his ability to hit a golf ball very, very far, tries to rustle up some money off of bets at the local links, and almost accidentally, with the help of Chubbs, the local pro who saw his own promising golf career come to and end after an unfortunate encounter with an alligator, finds himself on the pro golf tour.  Then there is the undeniably arrogant and completely unlikable bad guy, Shooter McGowan, whose place atop golf's elite is threatened by the young upstart Happy.  Of course, this kind of story calls for a leading lady, as well, and the businesslike yet increasingly desirable tour media director Virginia Venit (Julie Bowen) fits the bill to a tee (I swear this pun was entirely unintentional).Of course, the funniest parts of the movie take place on the golf course when the hockey-minded Happy takes out his early frustrations.  At his first pro event, he launches into one profanity-laced (mostly bleeped) tirade after another, throwing clubs, having in-your-face discussions with his uncooperative golf balls, and generally being very ungolfer-like.  Of course, the fans love it, so the PGA decides not to throw him out.  With Virginia's help, he manages to keep his behavior at a PG level, at least until the pro-am tournament.  Faced with a relentless heckler and a constantly complaining partner in Bob Barker, he snaps and has a go at Bob.  Hey, Bob Barker had it coming.  Faced with a month-long suspension, everything is on the line, both his grandmother's house and his own future golf career, at the PGA championship where he and Shooter compete for the gold jacket.  If you take away some of the profanity early on, Happy Gilmore is actually a pretty family-oriented little movie, and I for one certainly enjoy seeing the biggest underdog imaginable come out on top over the arrogant and despicable favorite.

reviewText: Adam Sandler is outstanding as Happy Gilmore, a wannabe hockey player (who is never good enough to make the team, but is great at fighting), who, when his grandmother's house is repossessed by the IRS because she hasn't paid her income taxes in ten years, takes a golf club from his late grandfather's bag, tees it up on the lawn, and launches a drive of nearly four hundred yards. The two workers, who are in the process of removing furniture from the grandma's house, can hardly believe their eyes. But when he repeats the feat two more times they are convinced. Although all Happy Gilmore wants is to become a hockey star, he enters a golf tournament, the winner of which will be allowed to compete on the pro tour. Despite a terrible short game (his putting is atrocious) he wins the tournament.Soon he is the talk of the tour. His drives of nearly four hundred feet are legendary, as are his antics, which are extremely flamboyant (to say the least) and are resented by the staid members of the tour. However, he is allowed to continue because the TV ratings are skyrocketing as a result of his antics. Conflict arises when Shooter McGavin (Christopher McDonald), who has never won the most prestigious tour event but is the favorite to do so, sees Gilmore as a real threat and does everything to thwart him. For his part, the only reason Gilmore wants to win tournaments is because he wants to make enough money to pay off his grandma's IRS bill so she can keep her house.This brief description of the basic plot is hardly adequate to convey how consistently funny this movie is. Let's just say that I laughed most of the way through it.At the same time, one has to suspend his disbelief for a number of reasons. Here are just a few instances: First off, Gilmore's unique approach of taking a running start before hitting his drives would never result in such picture-perfect and accurate drives as he almost always launches. Second, no one in real life hits drives approaching four hundred yards. Third, Gilmore's antics are so over the top that they would never be countenanced on the tour, no matter what the TV ratings might be, nor would he be allowed to so consistently violate the dress code.However, despite this, it's a great movie, and, if you watch it for its comedic effect and not as a portrayal of real life, you'll love it.
